channel.title: undefined vs. null in JavaScript
channel.description:
JavaScript distinguishes "undefined" and "null" in something of the way that Ren-C distinguishes unset and null variables. An undefined variable is one you haven't assigned yet, NULL is one you've set to NULL.
// Chrome Console Session > asdf VM66:1 Uncaught ReferenceError: asdf is not defined
> typeof asdf <- "undefined"
> asdf = null <- null
> asdf <- null
> typeof asdf <- "object"
*(If you're curious why the **typeof** null is an object in JavaScript: ["Because the spec says so. This is generally regarded as a mistake."](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/18808226/why-is-typeof-null-object). The move of not having an answer for the value of the type, e.g. saying the answer to **type of null** is null - is much better)*

item.title: undefined vs. null in JavaScript
item.dc:creator: hostilefork
item.description:
JavaScript distinguishes "undefined" and "null" in something of the way that Ren-C distinguishes unset and null variables. An undefined variable is one you haven't assigned yet, NULL is one you've set to NULL.

// Chrome Console Session
> asdf
VM66:1 Uncaught ReferenceError: asdf is not defined

> typeof asdf
<- "undefined"

> asdf = null
<- null

> asdf
<- null

> typeof asdf
<- "object"

(If you're curious why the typeof null is an object in JavaScript: "Because the spec says so. This is generally regarded as a mistake.". The move of not having an answer for the value of the type, e.g. saying the answer to type of null is null - is much better)

Read full topic

item.title: undefined vs. null in JavaScript
item.dc:creator: hostilefork
item.description:
This is how they deal with assignments:

> function nothing() { return; }

> let x = nothing()
<- undefined

> if (x) { console.log("it doesn't error even on dereference"); }
<- undefined

> if (!x) { console.log("because it's falsey"); }
because it's falsey
<- undefined

That's extremely forgiving...and not the direction we want to go in the "undefined" case.

(Not only does accessing variables holding NOTHING cause errors on access in Ren-C, ultimately we went with NOTHING as being truthy.)

Read full topic
